channel.title: WSJ.com: Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright © Dow Jones & Company, Inc. All rights reserved.

item.title: Swiss Inflation Held Steady in November
item.description: Consumer prices were steady on year, compared with a 0.1% rise posted in October.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Indian Rupee Hits Another Record Low as Capital Outflows, Tariff Risks Weigh
item.description: India’s rupee slipped to yet another fresh low on Wednesday, pressured by capital outflows and continued uncertainty about a trade deal with the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Kimberley Kao

item.title: Australia’s GDP Data Conceals Blistering Demand Growth
item.description: The initial reaction to Australia’s third quarter economic growth data on Wednesday was one of mild disappointment. But a deeper dive into the numbers reveals an economy bubbling along quiet nicely.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: China’s Services-Sector Activity Growth Slows
item.description: The RatingDog general services purchasing managers index fell to 52.1, marking the lowest level in five months, according to a statement released Wednesday.

item.title: Could $1,000 “Trump Accounts” for newborns, plus an additional $250 for some children 10 and under, convince Americans to have more kids?
item.description: They may not convince more people to have kids, but supporters say the accounts show the government is dedicating attention to children.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Wolfe

item.title: Australia’s Third-Quarter Growth Misses Estimates
item.description: The Australian economy grew by a little less than expected in the third quarter, with consumer spending, business investment growth, and strong government outlays supporting activity.
item.dc:creator: James Glynn

item.title: The Trump administration canceled interviews with a group of finalists to be the next Federal Reserve chair as Trump again suggested he had made up his mind about who should lead the central bank
item.description: The decision comes as Trump signaled publicly that longtime adviser Kevin Hassett is a leading contender to lead the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Nick Timiraos

item.title: Growth to Slow as Tariffs Bite, but AI Investments May Cushion the Blow
item.description: The OECD forecast the global economy to expand by 2.9% next year, a slowdown from 3.2% this year.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. manufacturing activity contracted for the ninth consecutive month in November, a decline manufacturers attribute largely to President Trump’s tariffs
item.description: Tariffs, which have increased costs for sourcing materials, continue to weigh on U.S. producers.
item.dc:creator: Chao Deng

item.title: The coming interest-rate decision by the Federal Reserve could be an unusually close call. Here’s a breakdown of the stance of the 12 policymakers who will vote on Dec. 10.
item.description: The December meeting is around the corner, and Fed Chair Jerome Powell is facing a divided body.
item.dc:creator: Quentin Webb

item.title: Bitcoin Falls as Prospect of Rate Rise in Japan Spooks Investors
item.description: BOJ Gov. Kazuo Ueda’s comments added to risk aversion and come against a backdrop of concerns about an overvaluation of tech stocks and other risky assets.
item.dc:creator: Renae Dyer

item.title: Rate Hikes Wouldn’t Put Brakes on Japan’s Economy, BOJ’s Ueda Says
item.description: The Bank of Japan will thoroughly discuss the possibility of an interest-rate increase at its coming meeting, Gov. Kazuo Ueda said, stoking hopes for a resumption of monetary tightening this year.
item.dc:creator: Megumi Fujikawa

item.title: Economists predicted a global shock from President Trump’s tariffs, but some of them are now revising their global growth predictions upward
item.description: Economists predicted a global shock from President Trump’s tariffs, but some of them are now revising their global growth predictions upward.
item.dc:creator: Stu Woo

item.title: China Private Gauge Signals Weaker Manufacturing Activity
item.description: Growth in China’s manufacturing production came to a halt as new orders nearly stalled last month despite a renewed rise in new orders from abroad.

item.title: More than other generations, 20-somethings are tightening their year-end spending. Here is why that is a problem for retail brands.
item.description: More than other generations, 20-somethings are tightening their holiday-season budgets because of economic pressures.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Williams

item.title: South Korea’s Export Growth Picked Up in November
item.description: South Korea’s exports rose at a stronger-than-expected pace in November, backed by brisk demand for semiconductors and a trade deal between Seoul and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Kwanwoo Jun

item.title: Charts show how President Trump has eased his levies—but some key ingredients might still weigh on consumers
item.description: Charts show how the president has eased his levies—but some key ingredients might still weigh on consumers.
item.dc:creator: Anthony DeBarros

item.title: Canadian Economy Rebounds by More Than Expected
item.description: Canada’s economy recovered far more strongly than anticipated in the latest quarter, pulled out of its decline by a bounce-back in net trade and a surge in defense spending that helped mask weak domestic demand.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: U.K. Home Sales Fall on Budget Uncertainty, Report Says
item.description: Sales fell 4% across the U.K., with buyer demand down 12% on year on fears of higher property taxes in the budget, according to a report by real-estate agency Zoopla.
item.dc:creator: Ian Walker

item.title: Jobless Claims Show Low-Hire, Low-Fire Environment Continues
item.description: The latest batch of weekly jobless-claims data brought more evidence Wednesday that the labor market is stuck in an uncertain neutral: layoffs subdued, but flagging hiring, too.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Shutdown-delayed data showed American consumers closed out the third quarter on a cautious footing, while a measure of consumer confidence tumbled in November
item.description: American consumers in September reined in spending on tariff-hit categories such as vehicles, electronics and clothing.
item.dc:creator: Harriet Torry

item.title: U.S. Home Prices Slow Further Amid Affordability Concerns
item.description: The S&P Cotality Case-Shiller National Home Price Index, which measures home prices across the country, rose 1.3% in the 12 months through September. This represents the weakest performance since mid-2023.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Parts of Europe at Risk of Downward ‘Spiral’ if Older Voters Stymie Reforms, EBRD Warns
item.description: Economies that escaped from Communism are at risk if older voters and political leaders prevent changes to offset aging populations.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: U.S. Employment Trends Improved in September Ahead of Shutdown
item.description: The Conference Board’s Employment Trends Index, or ETI, rose in September to 106.84 from an upwardly revised 106.68 in August, which was the lowest since early 2021, according to a delayed release.
item.dc:creator: Ed Frankl

item.title: How CEOs got more comfortable with tariffs: We analyzed 5,000 earnings calls to find out
item.description: Trump’s trade war is a pain, but less so than many executives expected.
item.dc:creator: Theo Francis

item.title: Thanksgiving might actually be cheaper this year
item.description: Turkey, stuffing and cranberry prices are all lower, but skip the yams. Sweet potato prices have skyrocketed.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Kuo

item.title: Canadian Retail Trade Remains Soft After Fall in September
item.description: Flat sales seen by Canadian retailers in October point to cracks in the consumers’ resilience as the fallout from the trade war with the U.S. lingers.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: Consumer Sentiment Fell in November, Michigan Survey Shows
item.description: The survey’s headline index dropped to 51, hovering near one of the lowest levels in the monthly poll’s history.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Home sales rose to an eight-month high in October, signaling how even a small decline in mortgage rates will attract some buyers back to the market
item.description: Falling mortgage rates spurred more activity in the beleaguered housing market, with sales moving higher for the second consecutive month.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Friedman

item.title: Labor Department Fills in Some Missing Jobless-Claims Data
item.description: A one-off data point has popped into view on the Labor Department’s website: a figure showing that 232,000 Americans filed new unemployment claims in the week through Oct. 18.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Threats to Eurozone Financial Stability ‘Remain Elevated,’ Says ECB’s De Guindos
item.description: A large-scale trade war has been averted, but uncertainty remains high about government policies that can affect the financial system, the European Central Bank vice president said.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: The reopened federal government will on Thursday release the first backlogged monthly jobs report, for the month of September
item.description: Widely anticipated labor data starts catch-up on backlogged economic reports after shutdown ended.
item.dc:creator: Matt Grossman

item.title: Heard on the Street: Borrowing from a builder might get you an eye-catching mortgage rate, but it also means you are more likely to overpay and potentially end up underwater
item.description: Borrowing from a builder might get buyers an eye-catching mortgage rate, but it also means they are more likely to overpay for the property—and potentially end up underwater.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: Rise in Key Interest Rate Hit Poorer Households Harder, ECB Economists Say
item.description: Europeans believe that income inequality has increased since the onset of the inflation surge.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Big employers are taking a more cautious approach to holiday hiring this year
item.description: Large companies say they are likely to add far fewer seasonal workers than in other recent years.
item.dc:creator: Jared Mitovich

item.title: Heard on the Street: New homes are sitting unsold, despite the discounted mortgages that builders are offering
item.description: New homes are sitting unsold, despite builders using sweeteners to shift inventory.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan
